ranked_diseases.explanation: Classic presentation with intellectual disability and hypertonia. Cerebral palsy commonly presents with both cognitive impairment and increased muscle tone, particularly in pediatric patients.
Features severe intellectual disability and can present with hypertonia, though hypotonia is more common early in life. The combination of symptoms fits the clinical picture.
Progressive neurological disorder with intellectual disability and hypertonia developing after initial normal development. More common in females but can occur in males with severe presentation.
Metabolic disorder that can present with intellectual disability and dystonia/hypertonia, particularly after metabolic crises. Age of presentation is consistent.
X-linked disorder presenting with intellectual disability and dystonia/hypertonia. More likely in males. Classic features include self-mutilation which is not mentioned.
Rare urea cycle disorder presenting with progressive spastic diplegia, intellectual disability, and hypertonia. Typically manifests in early childhood.
X-linked disorder with intellectual disability and mixed hypo/hypertonia. Males are affected. The limited phenotypic data makes this a consideration.
Leukodystrophy presenting with intellectual disability and spasticity/hypertonia. X-linked, affecting primarily males. Usually has additional features like nystagmus.
